paragraph_text: Kittle said he didn't inform the team he would be getting physical during the WWE match in April 2023. His philosophy was "just don't get hurt, and we won't have any problems with anything."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: That's the tightrope NFL players will be walking as they scatter for their offseason before training camp in late July. The standard NFL contract states guarantees could be voided if players are injured participating in activities with a significant risk of injury, and first-round picks often have specific endeavors listed. But teams can't monitor players 24/7, and history suggests incidents -- and injuries -- are inevitable.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "All the dangerous things," Kansas City Chiefs coach Andy Reid said when asked what he'd like his players to avoid. "Things where they get hurt, you don't want them to do."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: But "dangerous" is a relative term. Roster Management System scanned several contracts, and they all include prohibitions on things such as hang gliding, rock climbing and skiing. But there were some surprises.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes would void guarantees in his contract if he got hurt playing basketball, among other activities.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "When I was in Kansas City, basketball was the thing that you couldn't do," New Orleans Saints safety Tyrann Mathieu said. "I think somebody took a video of [Mahomes] playing basketball, and that's how that started, because then they didn't want anybody playing basketball."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Several contracts list basketball, although many players aren't shy about hooping in public. Dallas Cowboys linebacker Micah Parsons, Houston Texans QB C.J. Stroud, Los Angeles Rams receiver Puka Nacua and Chiefs receiver Mecole Hardman all participated in the NBA Celebrity All-Star Game in February. And Miami Dolphins star receiver Tyreek Hill recently posted a video of him dunking while playing with the Harlem Globetrotters.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "If it's basketball against guys that look like me, I'm good with it," Cleveland Browns coach Kevin Stefanski said with a laugh. "But the guys, they always need to be careful about whatever they're doing off the field.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "I'm like a mother hen. I just want everybody to be safe. I'd love to keep everybody locked in Berea [Ohio] in Bubble Wrap for the entire offseason."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: NACUA INTERCEPTED AN outlet pass near half court, dribbled up the left wing, flew by a defender and threw down a vicious, one-handed dunk. It was one of several aggressive moves by Nacua during the NBA celebrity game as he finished with 16 points, four assists and four rebounds.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Nacua is an avid basketball player, and there's nothing in his contract to specifically prohibit the former fifth-round pick from playing. Stroud, who was a first-round pick, would be in default if he got injured playing basketball, but he got clearance to play in the NBA celebrity game, according to a team source.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: It's unknown if Hill received permission to play with the Globetrotters.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "We did get some good runs in the offseason, but it's definitely winding down, especially since we got back out here," Nacua said recently during OTAs. "I'm like, 'My feet can't take that much burden.'

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "I'd say basketball would be the one thing that I've advised myself to stop doing [during the season]. It's like, man, we do so much running and cutting already, by the time I get there to Friday, I'm like, I don't know if I can even do a layup right now. I'm like, my hips and my knees hurt so bad. And changing surfaces has honestly been one of the things I've noticed as well. [Basketball courts] don't have soft grass."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: A post shared by Harlem Globetrotters (@harlemglobetrotters)

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Cleveland Browns All-Pro defensive end Myles Garrett was a high school letterman in basketball and grew up playing against his older brother, Sean Williams, who was a first-round pick of the New Jersey Nets in 2007.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: But after signing what was the richest contract extension for a non-quarterback in 2021, Garrett "retired" from playing pickup basketball, according to Stefanski.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "It's for the better now," Garrett said. "I'm still able to go to the gym and shoot, and every now and then get a little 2-on-2, 3-on-3 with the boys.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "But it's definitely the smarter approach not to be with a random person who has nothing to lose. In those instances, those are unknown variables that I'm playing around with that I just don't need to for the sake of the season or my career."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Garrett played in the 2022 NBA Celebrity All-Star Game, and although he was still feeling sore from the bumps and bruises of the season, he said he'd like to do that again.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "It definitely gives me that tingly feeling when I see guys in our sport hooping," he said. "I can't get rid of that love."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: While Stefanski retired Garrett from pickup games, some coaches have different philosophies. Atlanta Falcons assistant head coach Jerry Gray encourages players in the secondary to play hoops. Several Falcons players, including cornerbacks Clark Phillips III and Dee Alford and safety DeMarcco Hellams, go to a local gym in Flowery Branch, Georgia, near the team's facility to play pickup games during the offseason.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "That's the best thing for a defensive back," Gray said. "If you can cut in tight spaces, you can play corner. ... You learn how to play with four other guys. You learn how to keep vision on your man while you're looking at the backboard. You start learning how to rebound.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "All of those things start helping you intercept the football, because now you're not just focused on one guy. In basketball, you're actually covering everyone around you."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Falcons All-Pro safety Jessie Bates III said he hasn't gotten the invite to play with his secondary mates, because "they might be scared or something." Bates added he probably has "the best jumper on the team," and he does hit the court during the offseason with one of his best friends, Malik Williams, who played last year with the Toronto Raptors.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "I'm a three-sport athlete, so I try to play softball a little bit, try to go play basketball, because those things I think translate into the game of football," said Bates, whose contract does not prohibit basketball. "So yeah, I'm a hooper."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: NYHEIM HINES WAS sitting on a jet ski on July 2, 2023, when his watercraft was hit by another. The running back tore his left ACL and MCL, and his season with the Buffalo Bills was over before it started.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: The Bills put Hines on the non-football injury (NFI) list, meaning they were not required to pay him for the entire season. Buffalo had previously renegotiated a two-year, $9 million contract with Hines.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Ultimately, Hines and the team came to an agreement. According to Spotrac, Buffalo paid Hines $3.98 million in 2023. But the team released him on March 6, and he signed with the Cleveland Browns a week later.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "[The accident is] a terrible look, and that's been real hard," Hines told The Athletic in November. "If I was doing jumps or being stupid, I wouldn't even be really upset, but it's the fact that I literally wasn't even riding the jet ski. I was just getting gas."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Riding a jet ski is one of the more common prohibited activities in contracts. Riding all-terrain vehicles (ATVs) is another.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Former Seattle Seahawks defensive tackle Malik McDowell, the team's second-round pick in 2017, sustained a concussion in July 2017 in an ATV accident. He never played a down for the Seahawks because of the injury and the team sued, attempting to recoup almost $800,000 of his signing bonus. An arbitrator ruled McDowell forfeited that money by violating the standard language in his contract.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Former New York Giants safety Xavier McKinney, who's now with the Green Bay Packers, also sustained an injury riding an ATV. During the Giants' bye week last season, McKinney went to Cabo San Lucas, Mexico, and he had to undergo surgery with pins being placed in his left hand. The former Giants captain and defensive signal-caller missed seven games.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Other high-profile instances of injuries occurring during offseason activities include:

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Retired Colts quarterback Andrew Luck admitted two years after the fact that he aggravated his throwing shoulder injury in a 2016 Colorado snowboarding accident.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: In 2015, then-Giants linebacker Jason Pierre-Paul needed his right index finger amputated following a Fourth of July fireworks accident at his home.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Former Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger broke his jaw and nose in a 2006 motorcycle crash in which he was not wearing a helmet.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: It's no surprise that snowboarding, motorcycle riding and exploding fireworks are included among prohibited activities in many contracts.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "Pretty much everything off the field [is off limits]," Giants defensive lineman Dexter Lawrence said. "I like to play video games, so ..."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: MINNESOTA VIKINGS HEAD coach Kevin O'Connell was a quarterback for the New York Jets in 2010 when he got married to his then-fiancée, Leah. O'Connell attempted to appropriate the prohibited offseason activities language in his contract for his own purposes.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "I tried to use that clause to get out of dancing at my own wedding," O'Connell said with a laugh. "It didn't necessarily work, and I was able to make it through without any injury."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: On a more serious note, O'Connell said there has to be a discussion between coaches and players about what they should and should not be doing in the offseason.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "I think you have to [talk about it], just because there's been some examples of guys maybe getting an injury, and sometimes it's taking part in one of those reckless activities," he said. "Sometimes it's not.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "But that whole non-football injury world, that NFI world, it's the last thing you want to see as a coach because you know how impactful this game is already on guys' bodies."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Some coaches, like the Cincinnati Bengals' Zac Taylor, are in the camp of wanting to trust players to make the right decisions without having to feel like a babysitter.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "You can't just live in fear all the time if someone's going to get hurt or something," he said. "So, you got to go live your life and be healthy for us. ... I like to take players that are smart enough to know which things they should and shouldn't do."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Added Arizona Cardinals coach Jonathan Gannon: "I don't outline each guy's contract and what they can and what they can't do. But they know that their job as an Arizona Cardinal is to maximize themselves, and anything that takes away from maximizing themselves as a football player is not putting the team ahead of themselves."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Other coaches have specific things they'd like their players to avoid. Tennessee Titans coach Brian Callahan said he'd prefer his players "stay off of mountains."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: There are front-office executives, per sources, who have concerns about what the future looks like with flag football, which has been the centerpiece of the Pro Bowl Games the past two years.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: In 2028, the sport will make its debut in the Olympic Games, which will be hosted in Los Angeles. NFL executive vice president of football operations Troy Vincent said there is a likelihood of NFL players competing.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: .@jalenramsey needs a #ProBowlGames rules refresher asap 😂 pic.twitter.com/rI2anedtkQ

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: But even flag football is not without risk. Former Carolina Panthers receiver Steve Smith suffered a broken left forearm while playing flag football in 2010.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Days after the injury, Smith said: "I won't do it again. But I was just having fun, playing with some guys." And that's what Kittle was doing at WrestleMania: having fun.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Kittle is a massive pro wrestling fan and said he would have considered doing something with WWE again this year had he not had core muscle surgery this offseason. Instead, recently retired Philadelphia Eagles center Jason Kelce and his offensive line mate Lane Johnson did a run-in at WrestleMania in Philadelphia.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Kittle said when it comes to wrestling, he'd probably end up asking for forgiveness rather than permission. But if he did get injured while wrestling, he would be at risk of voiding his $100,000 workout bonus.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "I honestly am one of probably the safest guys," Kittle said. "I don't do anything.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: "I might occasionally be in a wrestling ring, but I'm not doing too much. I'm very aware football is everything, and so I don't even try to go skiing and stuff like that. That's not even on my mind."

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: But they are in his contract, and his general manager is watching.

title: What NFL players aren't supposed to do in the offseason
author: Marc Raimondi
paragraph_text: Additional reporting by Todd Archer, Sarah Barshop, DJ Bien-Aime, Brady Henderson, Stephen Holder, Daniel Oyefusi, Jordan Raanan, Michael Rothstein, Katherine Terrell and Nick Wagoner.

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: Tiger Woods expresses his frustration about his poor performance at Pinehurst and casts doubt on his future participation at the U.S. Open. (0:32)

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: The PGA Tour has created a special sponsor exemption for 15-time major champion Tiger Woods -- and Woods alone -- based on his "exceptional lifetime achievement," the tour told its members in a memo Tuesday night.

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: The sponsor exemption would be available for Woods to compete in the eight signature events, which feature limited fields, increased prize money and FedEx Cup points.

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: Woods, an 82-time winner on the PGA Tour, wouldn't otherwise qualify for the signature events with $20 million purses because he isn't playing enough competitive golf after returning to the tour from serious injuries suffered in a car wreck in February 2021.

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: The PGA Tour policy board approved the special sponsor exemption during a joint meeting with the PGA Tour Enterprises board of directors on Tuesday in Hartford, Connecticut.

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: In the memo, a copy of which was obtained by ESPN, the tour told its members, "An additional sponsor exemption will be created to recognize Tiger Woods in his own category as a player who has reached an exceptional lifetime achievement threshold of 80+ career wins."

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: This season, the eight signature events were The Sentry, AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am, Genesis Invitational, Arnold Palmer Invitational, RBC Heritage, Wells Fargo Championship, Memorial Tournament and the Travelers Championship.

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: In the memo, PGA Tour commissioner Jay Monahan said the policy board was considering implementing a 36-hole cut in each of the signature events -- only the Genesis Invitational, Arnold Palmer Invitational and the Memorial currently do. The board took no action and will continue discussing the topic.

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: The tour said it would also develop an alternate list that would ensure that each of the signature events had a field of 72 players. The Travelers Championship has only 71 players after Rory McIroy withdrew Monday.

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: Woods, 48, has competed in only nine official PGA Tour events the past three seasons since returning to action at the 2022 Masters. The only non-major event he has competed in is the Genesis Invitational at Riviera Country Club outside Los Angeles, which he hosts and benefits his foundation.

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: Woods withdrew from the second round of the Genesis Invitational in February because of illness. He finished 60th at the Masters and missed the cut at the PGA Championship and last week's U.S. Open.

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: Woods said he planned to compete in next month's Open Championship, scheduled for July 18-21 at Royal Troon Golf Course in Scotland.

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: When Woods was asked at the U.S. Open at Pinehurst No. 2 on Friday if playing in more events might help him perform better in the majors, he didn't seem ready to play additional tournaments.

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: "I've only got one more tournament this season," Woods said. "Even if I win the British Open, I don't think I'll be in the [FedEx Cup] playoffs. Just one more event and then I'll come back whenever I come back."

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: In the memo, Monahan also gave members an update on the tour's negotiations with Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund, which is considering a sizable investment in PGA Tour Enterprises. The PIF has funded the rival LIV Golf League the past three years.

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: Woods and other members of a transaction subcommittee met with PIF governor Yasir Al-Rumayyan and others in New York on June 7.

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: "As we've said in the past -- we can't negotiate in public -- but we are making progress," Monahan told the policy board, according to the memo. "Two weeks ago, members of our PGA Tour Enterprises transaction subcommittee met in New York with Yasir Al-Rumayyan, the Governor of the PIF, as well as members of his team. During that meeting, we reached consensus on several items, but both parties recognize that there is still work to do to reach a final agreement.

title: PGA Tour creates sponsor exemption for Tiger Woods, cites 'exceptional lifetime achievement'
author: Mark Schlabach
paragraph_text: "Our talks are ongoing, with the goal of developing a shared vision for the future of professional golf that is pro-competitive and provides players with the best global opportunities."

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: All of the teams in Euro 2024 have played their first games, and they gave us a bit of everything we could want.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Five teams scored at least three goals, and Germany scored five. Fans from Albania and Georgia, immense underdogs, each got to thunderously celebrate goals, one of which came just 23 seconds into Albania's match with Italy. Another underdog, Slovakia, got to celebrate a huge win over Belgium. England got to both win and be miserable, two things they very much enjoy.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: If you're a fan of last-minute fireworks, we got all we could want in Group F, with Georgia nearly scoring to tie Turkey before giving up an empty netter to fall 3-1 and Francisco Conceição scoring in the second minute of added time to finally pull Portugal ahead of the Czech Republic. (And if you're a fan of slapstick, we even got three own goals!)

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: The first round of matches at the 2024 European Championships was an absolute delight even if it didn't change a whole lot about the competition. The betting favorites before the tournament -- England, France, Germany, Portugal, Spain -- remain the favorites, and Belgium was the only even moderate favorite to lose.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: But let's overreact anyway. It's fun. Here are some takeaways from the first 12 matches of Euro 2024.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Germany's 5-1 win over Scotland was the stuff overreactions were made for. We got used to seeing demonstrative opening statements from Germany -- 8-0 vs. Saudi Arabia at the 2002 FIFA World Cup, 4-0 vs. Australia in 2010, 4-0 vs. Portugal in 2014 -- back when they were the most reliable and consistent country in the sport. Now, as they look for footing again after a number of stumbles, they produce a resounding, retro performance. And in front of a thrilled home crowd, no less.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Against a Scotland team that seemed bafflingly willing to open up the game early on, Germany were damn near perfect. The talismanic young combination of Florian Wirtz and Jamal Musiala combined to complete 61 of 63 passes (39 of 40 in the attacking third), and each scored brilliantly set-up goals -- Wirtz's assisted by Joshua Kimmich, Musiala's by Kai Havertz -- to put the game out of reach within 20 minutes. Granted, Scottish goalkeeper Angus Gunn probably should have done a bit more with Wirtz's effort, but the action was one-sided from the opening seconds.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Musiala successfully attempted five one-on-ones, and Toni Kroos had 32 combined progressive passes and carries; Scotland's entire team could only match those numbers, and they created six fewer chances than Germany's full-back duo of Kimmich and VfB Stuttgart's Max Mittelstadt. Germany even won 62% of the ball recoveries, which is a pretty decent proxy measure for pure hustle.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Julian Nagelsmann's recent decisions to (a) hand the keys of the attack to two 21-year-olds (Wirtz and Musiala) and (b) pair the beautifully controlled Kroos (102 passes, 101 completions) with Bayer Leverkusen's dirty-work master Robert Andrich in midfield, have completely changed the fortunes of the German national team over the past three months. Suddenly the squad has both energy and beautiful balance.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Even Antonio Rüdiger's incredibly flukey own goal was in its own way a sign of dominance: It allowed the hosts to make sure the visiting fans got to celebrate even while the visiting team never actually got to attempt a shot. (It went down as a shot attempt by Scott McKenna. We know better.) In my Euro 2024 preview, I said that Germany had been a strangely vibes-based team of late. Well, the vibes are pretty immaculate at the moment.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: In what was supposed to be one of the marquee early matches of the tournament between Spain (one of the most consistent tournament teams in Europe) and Croatia, Spain won comfortably 3-0.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Álvaro Morata and Fabián Ruiz both scored during a frantic five-minute period that saw both teams place a couple of shots on goal (and only one team's goalkeeper make saves), then Dani Carvajal knocked in a Lamine Yamal cross to put Spain up 3-0 at half-time. Croatia had a couple of nice sequences in the second half and earned a penalty, but Unai Simón batted away Bruno Petkovic's effort, and that was basically that.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Sam Marsden is impressed by the maturity shown from the Spanish starlet, who turns 17 the day before the Euro 2024 final.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: The match itself was as even as a three-goal finish can be, but Spain won for three primary reasons.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: 1. Simón was outstanding. Most of Croatia's shots came with defenders behind the ball, and they placed only five of their 16 shots on target, but the post-shot xG for those five shots, including the penalty, was a solid 2.4. Simon denied more than two expected goals' worth of shots.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: 2. Spain's finishing was surprisingly good. At Euro 2020 and the 2022 World Cup, Spain got stuck in a rut of draws. They won three matches and lost one, but they drew six times, three times in knockout-round matches (they won one penalty shootout and lost two). In those six draws, they scored four goals from shots worth a staggering 11.4 xG. For all of the brilliant passing Spain brings to the table, the actual shooting can abandon them. But not Saturday. Their three goals came from shots worth 1.9 xG, and I feel safe in saying that if Spain overachieves in that regard in this tournament, they immediately become one of the top three favorites, at worst.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: 3. Goodness, Yamal was good. And in such a unique way.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: In all 2023-24 matches in the UEFA Champions League and Europe's "Big Five" leagues, only four players combined the following stats: (a) shots worth at least 0.45 combined xG, (b) completed passes worth at least 0.35 expected assists (xA) and 0.7 expected point value added (xPVA), (c) at least nine progressive carries and (d) at least six one-on-one attempts.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: That's a unique combination of successful and frantic aggression, and it's something we typically only see in track-meet matches. Almería's Largie Ramazani did it in a 3-2 loss to Celta Vigo, for instance; Villarreal's Gerard Moreno (one of primary offenders in Spain's poor finishing spells in those previous tournaments) did it in a 3-2 loss to Athletic Club; and Yamal himself did it for Barca in a 5-3 loss to Villarreal. But then the 16-year-old did it again Saturday, adding exactly the right mix of aggression and general unpredictability to Spain's ball control game.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: For the most part, Spain controlled the ball in the midfield on the center and left, with midfielders Rodri and Ruiz, left-back Marc Cucurella and center-backs Nacho and Robin Le Normand completing a combined 234 passes. But their ability to occasionally release pressure and completely change the angle with long switches of play to Yamal consistently scrambled Croatia's defense and gave Yamal opportunities to challenge defenders in space.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Using the xG+xPVA combination we've discussed before (a really nice combination for determining who's completing dangerous passes and creating dangerous scoring opportunities for themselves and others), here are the Euro 2024 leaders after one matchday:

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: 1. Lamine Yamal, Spain (1.210 xG+xPVA, 86 minutes)2. Christian Eriksen, Denmark (1.190, 90 minutes)3. Andraz Sporar, Slovenia (1.060, 89 minutes)4. Antoine Griezmann, France (0.926, 89 minutes)5. Giorgi Kochorashvili, Georgia (0.844, 90 minutes)

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Four players between 24 and 32 years old, including two of the most creative veterans in the game ... and Yamal, the 16-year old. Ridiculous.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Yamal and left winger Nico Williams bring a level of aggression to the table that Spain often haven't had. Spain traded a bit of ball control for danger Saturday, and it looked good on them, even if their second-half lead protection efforts were a bit scattershot. (They did, after all, need Simon to come up big.)

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: But if Simon is playing well and Yamal is dancing defenders into the ground and completing dangerous crosses, this recipe could work for another six matches. Yamal was in diapers when Croatia's Luka Modric was playing at Euro 2008, but he could be the most valuable player for one of the most dangerous teams in the field.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: First, a history lesson: In the first game of Euro 2020, England beat Croatia 1-0 in a match in which, well, nothing really happened. Both teams attempted just eight shots, and neither team attempted much in terms of direct offense or pressure defense. England scored on a lovely and long sequence that finished with an even lovelier Kalvin Phillips-to-Raheem Sterling goal, but England mostly succeeded in sucking the life out of the game. They gave Croatia nothing and relied on an individual moment of brilliance in attack. It was as effective as it was underwhelming.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: In their next game, Scotland was able to make things a bit more hectic and attempted more shots (11 to nine), but England still didn't allow anything dangerous, and it ended in a scoreless draw. In the game after that, against the Czech Republic, Sterling scored early and England shut things down. They won 1-0 in a match with just 12 total shot attempts.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: It was impossible to be thrilled by England's play to that point, and you're intentionally minimizing your margin for error by satisfying yourself with 1-0 wins. Still, they produced seven points and an easy group win. And in wins over Germany and Ukraine in the knockout rounds, they attempted just 11 total shots but somehow scored on six of them and cruised. No one could force them to open things up, so they didn't.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: When Denmark took a 1-0 lead on them in the semis -- the first goal they had allowed all tournament -- they had to attack a bit more, and it looked great on them. It took them until extra time to work their way ahead in a 2-1 win, but they outscored the Danes 20-6 in the process. Then they took an early lead on Italy in the final with an unexpectedly swashbuckling start. (Let's not focus on what happened after that.)

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Dull doesn't equal bad, is the main point. I'm reminding myself of that as much as anyone reading this. Gareth Southgate's England aims to advance, not entertain, and they've figured out a pretty solid way of doing it. With Sunday's painfully dull 1-0 win over Serbia, they're now unbeaten in seven straight major tournament group stage games.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Man, it was painfully dull, though. England scored on their first shot of the match, a brilliant run and finish by Jude Bellingham on a deflected cross in the 13th minute, and they proceeded to attempt only three shots, all from long range, over the next hour. Harry Kane hit the post in the 77th minute, and that was it. They had five total shots, two worth more than a paltry 0.05 xG, but they allowed Serbia only six shots, none worth greater than 0.05. Phil Foden and Bukayo Saka created almost nothing of value -- it was Saka's deflected cross that produced the goal, at least, but he got no assist; Foden, meanwhile, sure does spend a lot of time in the middle for a left winger -- but it didn't matter.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Go ahead on a moment of brilliance, and then do your best to completely erase the clock. It's the English way, and I'm not falling for the dire undertones, at least not yet. Call this one an underreaction, I guess.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: If you only watch soccer during the major international tournaments -- don't do this, by the way; you're missing a lot! -- then at this point you've probably concluded that Romelu Lukaku is the worst finisher in the history of the sport.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: In the 2022 World Cup, Lukaku was limited to a bench role because of injury, but in Belgium's final group stage match against Croatia, with his team needing a win to advance, Lukaku put together some heroic work. On paper. In just 45 minutes, he attempted five shots worth a combined 1.7 xG. All of them came within 10 meters of the goal ... and none of them went into the net.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Fate was no kinder Monday in Belgium's 1-0 loss to Slovakia. In 90 minutes, Lukaku attempted three shots worth 0.8 xG, all within 10 meters again. In just the third minute, he got a decent leg on a transition opportunity (xG: 0.6) but hit it straight at goalkeeper Martin Dúbravka.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: He couldn't capitalize on two other chances, he missed what appeared to be a sitter on a chance that was eventually called offside and on two different second-half occasions, he scored goals that were disallowed, the first because he was offside by inches and the second because Loïs Openda, who assisted him on the goal, had nicked the ball with his hand earlier in the sequence. Both calls were correct and totally gut-wrenching.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: For the record, Lukaku has been awesome in a Belgium shirt throughout his career. The 31-year old scored 85 career goals for his country, 52 more than anyone else in Belgium's history, and in the past five years alone, he's scored 37 goals from shots worth just 28.8 xG. He has been an above-average finisher at worst in his career, but some of his most unfortunate moments have now come on the biggest possible stages. (I haven't even mentioned his ever-so-narrowly missed chances for Internazionale in the 2023 Champions League final yet.)

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Good or bad fortune aside, the result was huge. Both Group E matches were. Heading into the tournament, odds derived from ESPN BET gave Belgium a 94% chance of advancing, followed by Ukraine at 68%, Romania at 57% and Slovakia at 49%. Following Slovakia's win and a jarring 3-0 romp by Romania, here are the current odds:

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Percent change of advancing from Group E, per adjusted ESPN BET odds:

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Romania 88% (up 31%)Slovakia 81% (up 32%)Belgium 71% (down 23%)Ukraine 39% (down 29%)

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Eight teams in the European Championships saw their odds move either up or down by at least 20% in the first set of matches; that includes all four teams in Group E. Romania looked quite intriguing in Euro qualification and benefited from some hot finishing against Ukraine, and now they're the favorite to win the group, but if Belgium registers a strong rebound against Romania on Saturday, the odds could get shuffled up all over again.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: At least, the soccer coming from them is. (I assume the actual Alps, admired as they tend to be, are indeed properly rated.) I thought highly of Austria coming into the tournament and still do, but I also thought Switzerland might be prepped for a dud.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: The Swiss are battle-tested, having reached the round of 16 of their past five major tournaments and having knocked out France (and nearly Spain, too) in penalties at Euro 2020. But they had not played very well against Euro teams over the past year, losing to Romania and drawing with Romania, Denmark and Austria. They're also a little bit long in the tooth -- six of their 11 starters Saturday are 31 or older, and that doesn't even include injured 32-year-old Xherdan Shaqiri, who frequently starts.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Combine that with the fact that Hungary entered the tournament in lovely form and had the single best and most creative player on the pitch (Dominik Szoboszlai), and I was pretty confident Hungary was going to handle Switzerland on Saturday and stake a claim to second in Group A.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Form only sometimes matters in these tournaments, and making picks based on it can occasionally make you feel foolish. Switzerland scored early on a beautiful combination from Bologna's Michel Aebischer to Ludogorets Razgrad's Kwadwo Duah and put away a 3-1 win with a late Breel Embolo goal. Szoboszlai recorded a nice assist, but that was about it. Switzerland's experience shined through.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: In terms of qualification odds, this was the most impactful match outside of Group E -- again using odds derived from ESPN BET, Switzerland's odds of advancing jumped from 65% to 94%, while Hungary's dropped from 54% to 33%, both because they lost a winnable match and because they lost it by two goals.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Austria's odds of advancing, meanwhile, rose after their 1-0 loss to France on Tuesday. That says quite a bit. They couldn't stress France's Mike Maignan enough, attempting only six shots and putting three on goal, but they generated more touches in the attacking third, and they controlled the pitch for large portions of the match. They forced France's defenders to make strong individual plays -- being that said defenders are elite, they indeed made those strong plays -- and gave a good account of themselves in Dusseldorf.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Switzerland now has a 94% chance of advancing to the knockout rounds, while Austria's odds are holding steady at 55% and would surge with a win over Poland in Berlin on Friday. I listed them as sleepers to make a run in the knockout rounds, and I'm sticking to that. I just should have chosen Switzerland to do the same.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Or at least some place that's actually accessible. Put a tournament in an accessible and affordable location, and watch all of Europe show up.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: Put a tournament in the home of the Bundesliga, and watch everyone start playing like a Bundesliga team. We haven't been completely violence-free, we weren't completely without first-match duds -- yes, hello, England -- and the world has officially been exposed to the fact that the German train system isn't nearly as good as it once was. But the goals are flowing, and the scenes around the matches have been mostly delightful.

title: Euro 2024 first-game overreactions: Can anyone stop Germany?
author: Bill Connelly
paragraph_text: After two straight World Cups in faraway and relatively foreboding places (Russia and Qatar), and with travel restrictions severely limiting mobility at the first post-COVID Euros, this is the first time since Euro 2016 in France that access has been reasonably easy and affordable. It's amazing what a difference that makes.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: Check out some of the top college highlights from new Commanders quarterback Jayden Daniels. (1:42)

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: ASHBURN, Va., -- One of Jayden Daniels' worst throws this spring occurred in front of the largest crowd he has encountered since becoming a member of the Washington Commanders. And afterward, all he could do was smile.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: Throwing out the first pitch at a Washington Nationals game earlier this month, the Commanders' latest great hope at quarterback pulled his effort into the left-handed batter's box.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "It's a good thing he's throwing here and not down at the ballpark," Commanders coach Dan Quinn said, smiling.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: The errant pitch was one of the few times Daniels has left observers unimpressed this spring. Otherwise, the No. 2 pick in the 2024 draft has left a favorable early imprint on his teammates and coaches. They know more steps remain. He has yet to face a live pass rush, an opposing defense or anyone in pads. Teammates and coaches have pointed that out; they also acknowledge there will be both good and bad days ahead as Daniels develops. But after getting a first glimpse of the hours he puts in at the facility, his ability to call, make and direct plays on the field and his engaging personality -- they cannot wait to see how he progresses.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "Dude can sling it man," right tackle Andrew Wylie said. "He makes it look easy. Something about his game is just special."

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: Before Daniels, Washington had drafted five other quarterbacks in the first round from 1994 to 2019: Heath Shuler, Patrick Ramsey, Jason Campbell, Robert Griffin III and Dwayne Haskins. They combined to go 51-86 as starters for Washington, with one Pro Bowl selection (Griffin). Only Campbell served as the primary starter for four years; he is also the only one who started 12 or more games in three different seasons.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: Now comes Daniels, the Heisman Trophy winner who became a No. 2 pick -- just like Griffin in 2012 - who the Commanders are hoping can finally bring stability to the position.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "He's a rookie," one member of the organization said of Daniels. "There's still a lot to learn. At the same time, he's on course."

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: THIS SPRING, TEAMMATE after teammate mentioned how early Daniels arrived at the Commanders' facility.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "He always beats me here, so I think that's pretty cool," said defensive tackle Jonathan Allen, who arrives at 6:45 a.m.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "You start to doubt yourself a little bit," said guard Nick Allegretti, who arrives at 6:30 a.m. "You think you're one of the early guys and then he looks like he'd been here for a minute. He is bright eyed. I'm dragging in at 6:30 so I'm going to work on it, maybe get here at six."

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: It is what he did at LSU, too. Rookie receiver Luke McCaffrey has been joining Daniels in Washington.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: The two players watch film, then head to the practice bubble to walk through plays.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "I'm still learning the playbook and trying to grasp everything," Daniels said. "So just being comfortable for a day and being ready to go out there and go out and compete."

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: The result: A young quarterback who teammates and coaches say is ahead of schedule in learning the offense and particularly the protections.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "His football IQ is really high," offensive coordinator Kliff Kingsbury said. "[With] protections, I've been really impressed by that. A lot of guys coming into the league, that's not an area that they major in in college. They don't have a lot of time. But he's well-versed in protections and works at it."

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: As a result, Daniels rarely makes mistakes when calling plays in the huddle and rarely needs coaches to repeat one, according to Quinn, who listens in on the headset.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "He's further along than you probably should be," Quinn said.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "He's a student of [the game]," quarterbacks coach Tavita Pritchard said, "but he just loves it. He loves talking about it, loves watching it, loves playing it, loves practicing it."

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: DANIELS HAS GOTTEN attention for his play on the field, too.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: One play, Daniels scrambled outside of the pocket and lofted a perfect pass downfield, over the arms of a defender. On another, one team staffer recalled, when as a receiver was about to cross behind a linebacker, Daniels released the ball -- anticipating his target getting open -- for a completion.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "After the second or third crosser that he threw, I started telling receivers, 'Hey, you got to get your head around,'" receiver Terry McLaurin said. "A lot of quarterbacks may like to see you cross the ball and get into that open zone. Or if it's man [coverage] they like to see you get open for him. He can make those throws and give you a chance to catch and run."

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: On another play, the defense tried to confuse him with pre-snap movement. Daniels paused, signaled to players on both sides of the formation; used a hard count to get the defense to reveal its intentions -- one coach called it a veteran move -- took the snap and connected with tight end Ben Sinnott on a quick hitch against a blitz.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "Our quarterbacks have a lot of freedom to get to things that they're able to attack a defense based on what they're seeing," Pritchard said. "You're seeing him applying those things that he's learned in the meeting room."

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: After misfires, Daniels often talks to one of his teammates. Tight end Zach Ertz usually can be seen with him after a series, motioning with his hands as if discussing a route. McLaurin and running back Austin Ekeler have said Daniels asked them to stay after practice so he can work on throwing to a particular route.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "I don't think I've had a young quarterback that really has come in and within the first week he's like, 'Hey, can we get this rep after practice?'" said McLaurin, who has played with 10 different starting quarterbacks since joining the organization in 2019. "It makes the growth part a lot quicker."

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: Not only his play, but Daniels' patience and poise in the pocket has also stood out.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "A lot of guys panic and try to force the throw or just run but he's comfortable back there and he's looking to make a play down the field," Allegretti said. "A lot of rookies just put their head down and run. That's been the biggest thing that's jumped out."

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: DANIELS SMILES ALL the time when he is not taking snaps. Even when engaged in friendly trash talk with fellow rookie quarterback Sam Hartman during a pre-practice drill, the smile never left his face.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "He's very charismatic," McLaurin said. "He's really personable when he walks into the building, very approachable."

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: One staffer said he sees Daniels eating breakfast at a different table, with different players, nearly every day.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: When Daniels met special teams standout/backup safety Jeremy Reaves for the first time, the rookie approached him and said, "Hey, what's up Reavo?"

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "That speaks volumes about the guy, that he's taking the time to know everybody," Reaves said.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "We've sat and talked, we've talked ball. On the first day [of practice] I had a pick against him, and I told [him], 'Hey, if you leave this ball more behind him, it makes it harder for me out of the post to come make this play.' He's open to constructive criticism and that's what you want. With franchise guys like that, what matters most is who they are off the field, how they are in the locker room with the guys."

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: Daniels said he likes talking to as many teammates as possible, especially on the field, to help him learn.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "You're trying to soak up as much as possible and you got guys like Bobby [Wagner] that've been playing at a high level for a very long time, so as much as I could be around them and pick their brain, I'm willing to do that," Daniels said.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: QUINN HAD A plan to divide first-team reps among his quarterbacks this spring. Before last week's mandatory minicamp, Marcus Mariota took the majority of the first-team snaps. Once minicamp began, that share went to Daniels, along with snaps from projected starting center Tyler Biadasz during pre-practice drills.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: That is why, Quinn said, no declaration has been made on if Daniels will enter training camp as the starter.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "There's no doubt that Jayden's making unbelievable progress here," Quinn said. "It was really clear that he's put in the work.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "He's got a swagger to him. He really has a very firm handle on the things that we're doing, but he also has the humility of a young player ... knowing he has a lot to prove."

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: But there is much more to learn and more situations for Daniels to endure. He still must face defenses designed to fool him; he still must prove he can consistently make the necessary tight-window throws, particularly in the red zone. And how will he handle an NFL pass rush once the pads go on?

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: During one hurry-up series last week, Daniels missed on multiple passes as the pocket tightened. He overthrew tight end Cole Turner down the field on a deep crosser. On the next play, Daniels attempted a checkdown to Ekeler, but the ball landed at his feet.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: Daniels said he will work out this summer in Southern California with his quarterback coaches and possibly some of the Commanders' receivers. He will continue to study the playbook and, as he said, "get ready for the season."

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: He knows he still must prove what he can do in the fall. It is part of the growth process for any rookie quarterback, even those who have made such a strong first impression.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "I ain't a star quarterback yet," Daniels acknowledged last week. "I've got a long way to go."

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: Ekeler, who played his first seven NFL seasons with the Chargers, has played with a longtime starting quarterback in Philip Rivers as well as a rookie in Justin Herbert. He knows that while the spring was a key step for Daniels, it is just one of many.

title: First impressions of Commanders rookie QB Jayden Daniels
author: John Keim
paragraph_text: "It's hard to tell anything until you get to the preseason to see how it's playing out," Ekeler said. "But I'm proud of the strides he's made so far."

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Have you ever debated your friends about the NFL's best young players? Or maybe wondered about the top players ... who are older than you? Well, so did we.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: We set out to pick the best active football players at as many ages as possible, spanning the NFL, college and high school. We tapped NFL analyst Matt Bowen, draft analyst Jordan Reid and ESPN high school recruiting coordinator Billy Tucker to make their selections, leaning in on how dominant each player is right now. The result is 27 players, hitting ages 40 through 14.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: The best player at age 40 was easy to pick, because three-time league MVP Aaron Rodgers is making his comeback from an Achilles injury. After that, though? It gets difficult. Patrick Mahomes or Myles Garrett at age 28? What about Penei Sewell, Sauce Gardner, Puka Nacua, Aidan Hutchinson or Kyle Hamilton at age 23?

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Let's get into the picks, starting at Rodgers and counting down to players just entering high school. (Tucker handled ages 14-18, Reid picked for 19-22 and Bowen did 23-40.) There are a few players who have summer birthdays; we used the publication date (June 13) as the age cut off. We have key stats to know, notes on how each player has dominated and more.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Key stat to know: Rodgers has won four NFL MVP awards, second in league history to Peyton Manning's five. His most recent was in 2021, when he threw 37 touchdown passes and four interceptions.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Why he's the best at his age: Rodgers was limited to four regular-season snaps in New York last season due to a season-ending Achilles tear, but he showed in 2022 he still has top-level arm talent. At this stage of his career, his rushing totals and scramble attempts have declined, but he remains one of the best pure throwers in the game, using his quick release to deliver the ball with anticipation and location.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Over 19 NFL seasons, he has thrown 475 touchdown passes, and he has another 35 scores as a runner.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Key stat to know: Flacco threw 13 touchdown passes in five starts for the Browns last season, topping 300-plus passing yards in four of those.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Why he's the best at his age: The Browns turned to Flacco late last season, and he led them to a 4-1 record from Weeks 13-17, as Cleveland earned a spot in the wild-card game versus the Texans. He threw two picks in a blowout loss, however.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: The 16-year veteran has thrown for 43,936 yards during his career, and he will enter the 2024 season as the primary backup to Anthony Richardson in Indianapolis after signing a one-year deal with the team this offseason.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Key stat to know: Morstead had 36 punts that landed inside the 20-yard line last season, which ranked second in the league.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Why he's the best at his age: Morstead was busy last season after Rodgers was injured in Week 1 -- his 99 punts led the league. He averaged 48.8 yards per kick, with a net average of 41.8.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Originally drafted in 2009 by the Saints, he has played in 238 career games, logging 41,972 punt yards. And he has had just one punt blocked during his career in 897 attempts.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Key stat to know: Campbell had six sacks in Atlanta last season, pushing his career total to 105.5.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Why he's the best at his age: At 6-foot-8 and 282 pounds, Campbell has the strength and versatility to align in multiple fronts as an edge or interior defender. In addition to his sack totals last season, he had 28 QB pressures and 56 total tackles.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Campbell just signed with Miami ahead of his 17th NFL season, and he can make an impact on a defense that has been overhauled this offseason.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Key stat to know: Stafford put up a QBR of 63.5 last season, which ranked sixth in the league.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Why he's the best at his age: After an injury-plagued and inconsistent 2022 season, Stafford played in 15 games for the Rams in 2023 and had 3,965 passing yards with 24 touchdown passes and 11 interceptions. He has topped the 4,000-yard mark nine times in his career, most recently during L.A.'s Super Bowl-winning season in 2021.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: A natural passer with an aggressive mentality and the arm talent to attack every spot on the field, Stafford can still light up opposing defenses in Sean McVay's offense. He's also one of the league's toughest players.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Key stat to know: Williams had a pass block win rate of 95.8% last season, which ranked No. 1 among all offensive tackles.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Why he's the best at his age: The best left tackle in the NFL, Williams is an explosive run-blocker with the traits and movement skills to consistently secure the pocket in pass protection. Last season -- his 14th in the league -- he allowed just one sack.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: He has posted a pass block win rate of 92% or higher in each of his four seasons with the 49ers. He's a dominant talent who was named first-team All-Pro in each of the past three seasons, and he has made 11 Pro Bowl teams.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Key stat to know: Kelce caught 32 of his 37 targets for 355 yards and three touchdowns during the Chiefs' playoff run last season, which ended in another Super Bowl title.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Why he's the best at his age: Before a 984-yard receiving season in 2023, Kelce had produced seven straight years of at least 1,000 yards. Still the top target for quarterback Patrick Mahomes, he is a savvy route runner who can set up coverage and find open voids, creating matchup issues for defenses at all three levels of the field. With his ability to run after the catch, Kelce creates explosive play opportunities in Andy Reid's pass game.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Kelce has been the model for receiving production at the tight end position, and he has a case as the best player at the position in league history.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Key stat to know: Martin has produced a pass block win rate of at least 92% in the seven seasons ESPN has been tracking offensive linemen blocking metrics.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Why he's the best at his age: Martin is still a staple of the Dallas offensive line as he heads into his 11th season. In the 15 games he played in 2023, he had a pass block win rate of 92.1% while posting a run block win rate of 75.4%, which ranked 10th among guards.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Martin, who has been named first-team All-Pro seven times, uses his movement traits and instincts to secure the interior and create daylight in the run game.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Key stat to know: In just 13 games last season, Allen turned 22 third-down receptions into first downs, which tied for the fifth-most in the league.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Why he's the best at his age: Allen is a highly skilled route runner with the elite coverage awareness to find open grass. He finished last season with 103 receptions despite missing four games due to injuries. He has produced 904 receptions over 11 seasons.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Allen was traded to Chicago this offseason, and he will operate as a top target with chain-moving ability for rookie quarterback Caleb Williams.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Key stat to know: Thuney's pass block win rate of 99.1% led all offensive linemen during the 2023 season.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Why he's the best at his age: In 643 pass-block reps for the Super Bowl champs last season, Thuney was credited with just four losses, and he surrendered just one sack. A technically sound interior lineman, he can win with positioning or power. He has the foot quickness to shut down defensive tackles to keep the pocket firm.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Thuney signed a five-year contract with the Chiefs in free agency in 2021, and he remains one of the highest-paid guards in the league. He was named first-team All-Pro last season for the first time in his career.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Key stat to know: Hill has posted back-to-back seasons with 1,700-plus receiving yards.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Why he's the best at his age: Hill is arguably the most feared receiver in the league since Randy Moss, due to his blistering speed and explosive play ability. He tied for the NFL lead in receptions of 20-plus yards (25) and touchdown grabs (13) last season. He's a vertical threat from both boundary and slot alignments, and the pre-snap movement in Mike McDaniel's system allows him to get free releases into his routes.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Hill ranks fifth among active pass-catchers with 76 career receiving touchdowns, and he has been named a first-team All-Pro five times in his career, including in both of his seasons in Miami.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Key stat to know: Watt has forced 27 fumbles in seven seasons, the most of any defender during that stretch.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Why he's the best at his age: Watt's 19 sacks last season led the league, and he has 96.5 in his career. That ranks eighth among active players, and he still hasn't hit age 30.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: A savvy rusher who uses speed, power and technique to set up offensive tackles, Watt is a natural disruptor. In addition to the forced fumbles, he has batted down 28 passes and grabbed seven interceptions in his career. The 2021 Defensive Player of the Year is a game-changer who creates impact plays for the Pittsburgh defense.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Key stat to know: Mahomes has thrown for 4,000-plus yards in each of his six seasons as the Kansas City starter. He has played in four Super Bowls over that stretch, winning three titles.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Why he's the best at his age: The two-time regular-season MVP and three-time Super Bowl MVP uses his vision and anticipatory skills as a thrower to attack voids, while leaning on his rare instincts and second-reaction ability to make off-schedule plays. He is also one of the league's best scramblers, as he has 1,881 rushing yards on scramble attempts in his career while converting 117 first downs.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Mahomes, who signed a contract extension worth $450 million in 2020, is the unquestioned best quarterback in the game today.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Key stat to know: Jackson had a career-high 3,678 passing yards while adding 821 rushing yards last season, picking up his second career regular-season MVP award.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Why he's the best at his age: Jackson remains the league's premier dual-threat talent at the quarterback position. He completed 67.2% of his passes in 2023, and he has rushed for more than 750 yards in five straight seasons. He combines excellent arm talent and electric movement ability to create consistent conflict for opposing defenses. And he has found the right offensive fit under coordinator Todd Monken, who creates space -- both vertically and horizontally -- for Jackson to attack as a runner and thrower.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Jackson, who signed a five-year contract extension for $260 million last year, hasn't had the same success as Mahomes in the playoffs, as the Ravens are just 2-4 in his postseason starts.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Key stat to know: Bosa's 44.5 sacks over the past three seasons rank third behind T.J. Watt (47) and Myles Garrett (46).

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Why he's the best at his age: The NFL's best speed-to-power rusher, Bosa has the ability to uproot offensive tackles at the point of attack, collapsing the edges to create pass-rush production. He had 10.5 sacks (and 56 QB pressures) last season after a league-high 18.5 in 2022. The tape also shows he is a highly skilled technician who attacks the edges of blockers, while using his short-area burst to get home off twists and stunts.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
paragraph_text: Bosa signed a five-year, $170 million extension last year, making him the league's highest-paid defensive player.

title: Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40
author: Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker
